title: Attitude: Drive Calmly, Share the Road
summary: Adopt the considerate, law-abiding mindset that keeps traffic flowing smoothly and protects vulnerable people.

sections.title: Why Attitude Matters
sections.body: Your attitude shapes every decision behind the wheel. DVSA examiners look for patient, collaborative driving that keeps everyone safe and confident.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Rule 147: Be patient and courteous with every road user, especially the vulnerable.
Rule 126: Maintain at least a two-second gap in the dry, four seconds in the wet.
Rules 219–221: Give priority to emergency vehicles without breaking traffic laws.

sections.title: Skills to Develop
items: Plan journeys with buffer time so you never feel pressured to speed or take risks.
Use calm communication—signals, positioning, and eye contact—to share space politely.
Practise breathing and grip relaxation techniques to manage stress responses.
sections.body: Attitude skills are practical. Build them on routine drives by setting small goals, such as keeping generous gaps or thanking drivers who let you merge.

sections.title: Handling Conflict Safely
items: Avoid retaliation if others drive aggressively; reduce speed and create space instead.
Keep doors locked and remain in your vehicle if you feel threatened; call 999 if necessary.
Do not make eye contact or gestures that may escalate the situation.

sections.title: Protect Vulnerable Road Users
sections.body: Cyclists, pedestrians, horse riders, and mobility scooter users need extra room and patience. Slow right down, give at least 1.5 m when passing cyclists under 30 mph, and follow instructor guidance around horses.

checklist.label: I leave early and have a plan for delays so I never feel rushed.
I use signals, positioning, and eye contact to cooperate with others.
I maintain legal speed limits and time-based following gaps.
I adapt speed and give wide clearance to vulnerable road users.

practiceTips.label: Plan for pressure
practiceTips.detail: List three situations that usually raise your stress (tailgaters, running late, busy junctions). Decide the calm response before you drive.

practiceTips.label: Positive reset
practiceTips.detail: At every red light, name one thing going well. It keeps your mindset supportive and reduces frustration.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s cue
practiceTips.detail: If someone makes a mistake, count to three before reacting. That pause protects your licence and keeps journeys smooth.

questions.prompt: An emergency vehicle approaches from behind with blue lights flashing. What should you do?

options.label: Brake sharply and stop in the middle of the lane
options.explanation: Stopping suddenly may cause a collision or block the emergency vehicle.

options.label: Continue at the same speed until you reach your destination
options.explanation: Failing to respond delays emergency services and breaks Highway Code guidance.

options.label: Signal and pull over where it’s safe, without mounting the kerb or breaking red lights
options.explanation: Give emergency vehicles space, but only when it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.prompt: A driver behind is tailgating you on a national speed limit road. What’s the best response?

options.label: Accelerate to increase the gap
options.explanation: Speeding up reduces your own safety margin and may break the speed limit.

options.label: Brake test them to warn them off
options.explanation: Braking sharply could cause a collision and may be interpreted as aggression.

options.label: Maintain a steady speed and increase the gap ahead so you can slow gradually if needed
options.explanation: Creating extra space ahead keeps you and your passengers safe while discouraging tailgating.

questions.prompt: You’re feeling stressed after a difficult day. What should you do before driving?

options.label: Jump in the car and get the journey over with
options.explanation: Driving while upset can lead to poor decisions and aggressive responses.

options.label: Take a short break, breathe deeply, and delay the journey if you still feel tense
options.explanation: A calm mindset helps you drive considerately and meet DVSA expectations.

options.label: Turn the radio up loud to distract yourself
options.explanation: Loud music won’t resolve stress and may distract you from hazards.

questions.prompt: How should you respond if another driver makes a mistake that delays you?

options.label: Sound the horn repeatedly to show your frustration
options.explanation: The horn is only for warning others of danger, not expressing annoyance.

options.label: Stay patient, allow them space, and continue once the hazard is clear
options.explanation: Patience keeps everyone safe and demonstrates the positive attitude examiners expect.

options.label: Overtake immediately, regardless of road markings
options.explanation: Dangerous overtakes risk collisions and are unlawful.
